Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: As a math and cs major, I gained no skills by taking this course; I just trained my memory skills. I got an A with ease.

First-order, second-order, nth-order linear ordinary differential equations, modelling problems, series solutions (Frobenius method), Laplace transforms, Fourier series and partial differential equations.
I learned how to identify and solve a variety of different ordinary and partial differential equations.
Differential equations.
This course covers a lot of material. Solid foundation in the most of ordinary differential equations and the basics of partial differential equations.
Methods of solving ordinary and partial differential equations.
I learned, too well, the processes involved with solving differential equations. What she taught, ended up learning.
I gained a good knowledge of differential equations and how they're used in engineering practices.
Really great in depth intro to solving differential equations

We learned to solve many ordinary differential equations and some partial differential equations. 1st order, 2nd order, higher order, matrix methods, series solutions, euler equations, series solutions at singular points, laplace transforms, fourier series, and parabolic, ellliptic, and hyperbolic pardital diferential equations).
Pretty comprehensive overview of methods for solving ordinary differential equations with a little bit on partial differential equations at the end

I learned how to solve ordinary differential equations, as well as partial differential equations. Partial differential equations were only covered in the last two or three weeks of lectures, however. More specifically, we learned how to solve first-order, second-order, and nth-order differential equations, both with constant and variable coefficients. Many methods were covered, but they were more easily remembered than, say, mechanisms in organic chemistry.

I developed the skills necessary to solve differential equations by taking this course. I learned how to use undetermined coefficients, reduction of order, variation of parameters, matrices, series, Laplace transforms, separation of variables, and Fourier series to solve ordinary and partial differential equations.
I learned several techniques to solve ordinary differential equations, and one method of solving partial differential equations. There were also some reviews of linear algebra and integral calculus.

This course taught us how to solve most solvable ODEs through different methods, like separation of variables, variation of parameters, method of undetermined coefficients, matrix methods, series, and Laplace, as well as some PDEs through separation of variables and the Fourier transform. This class teaches us to look at a differential equation, determine which type of equation it is, and solve it through the above methods. This course is really comprehensive and after taking the course you will have a strong grasp of solving these problems for other classes in engineering and other STEM fields.
Solving differential equations, along with some basic algebra (you don't need to have taken MATH 222)
Knowledge of basic ordinary differential equation solving methods.
The class provided a good set of methods for evaluating differential equations, although does not include significant discussions of the mathematical basis.
I learned a lot about solving differential equations and a bit (probably spent about 4 lectures) about partial differential equations.
Learned a lot of material about differential equations. the course definitely picked up by the end, and when studying for the cumulative final I really realized that we learned so much.
Mostly linear ordinary differential equations, but we covered a bit on linear partial differential equations.

I gained an understanding of differential equations, and began to develop a basic intuition of how to solve them (i.e., only linear ODES and some PDES.) To solve ordinary differential equations, I learned the methods of integrating factors, undetermined coefficients, and unknown variables, how to use Laplace Transforms, and the application and determination of eigenfunctions; and for solving certain partial differential equations I learned how to apply separation of variables.
I also used differential equations to model a few (very) basic physical scenarios.
Deep understanding of all the methods related to dealing with Ordinary Differential Equations (and a little bit on the ones for Partial Differential Equations).
How to solve differential equations
Learned differential equations and problem solving- knowing and deciding the best way to approach each problem based upon known methods.

How to solve a variety of ordinary and partial differential equations> Most of the course focused on ordinary differential equations and the last few weeks were devoted to partial differential equations.
Learned how to solve ordinary, linear differential equations using a variety of techniques. Also did some stuff with partial diff eqs, but not that much. Mainly just separation of variables.
I learned various methods to solve particular differential equations

General understanding of different methods for solving differential equations, as well as general problem solving skills, and solidifying earlier calculus skills. Some application too, like heat conduction, waves, population dynamics, springs, etc.
How to solve differential equations

I learned how to solve narrow sets of differential equations. I feel like I understand more about how differential equations work now, but I think that the ways they are categorized so that we can solve them in a simple way is very arbitrary. I didn't feel like I understood how all the material connected until the final exam.
I learned to solve ordinary differential equations mostly, and a couple of partial ones too.
mostly ODEs, some PDEs, etc. If you were lost in your intro physics class when the prof started talking about harmonic oscillators/waves, take this class!
This course is very well designed, but it covers an overwhelming amount of material. Linear algebra should be listed as a prerequisite, though.

This course, despite being very advanced, is excellent. It is fast-paced, but effective lectures and psets really facilitate learning. Dr. Bennet is the best professor I have had at Yale so far. Exams are somewhat challenging, but if you invest the time to really learn the material, they are manageable. The only thing I would improve would be reducing the class size, but it didn't significantly impede my learning.
Very relevant to physics! Take this over Phys301 or Math246. I found it fascinating and easier to understand. Far more focused on problem solving and quickly relevant in physics classes.

This course was well structured. Assignments matched the lecture material and the written lecture notes were fantastic. The course does cover a lot of material and that can be daunting at the end of the semester.

The course could be improved by having review sessions before the exams and having practice exams. We only did problems from the textbook on homework so it was really difficult to understand the exam problems.
This was one of the most organized classes I've ever taken. Professor Bennett was always incredibly clear and meticulous in her expectations and explanations.

The class was structured around being given a very specific type of differential equation and memorizing the process to solve that equation. There was no context given in terms of geometrically or algebraically explaining what the differential equations looked like or we were doing in the process of solving them. The "application" sections, too, were very monotonous and not broadly applicable.

Despite having to cover a huge amount of material, the class was well organized and well taught. Professor Bennett did a great job making some of the more complicated math accessible to everybody, and the lecture notes she provided after every class are better even than the textbook.

Beth is an incredible teacher and probably the only person I could learn differential equations from. Her notes were precise and I learned from them so well, and her lectures were very clear. It's a class with a lot of very very smart people, so I wish there was a little more wiggle room in terms of grades - possibly three midterms with one dropped midterm, or you could take the final grade in the place of one midterm. In the end, I feel like I mastered the material (good grades on the finals) but didn't get a good overall grade because of one midterm that I thought was challenging, which is a little frustrating. The psets were reasonable and the final was challenging but not too ridiculous. I wish we spent more time on PDE's - if we had done the beginning few concepts in the course faster (they were pretty easy to understand) perhaps we could have! Wish there was more midterm practice material but otherwise a very good course.

The course moves super fast because it covers ordinary and some partial differential equations, but I guess since it's meant for engineers it's better to combine all you need into one semester. The biggest strength is Beth Anne Bennett teaching this class, it could be improved by having her teach it forever.

This is the most organized course I've every taken at Yale! Dr. Bennett posts very clear expectations, lecture notes, handouts, problem sets, problem set solutions, and other resources well in advance. The content can be boring and confusing at first, but this course is extremely well structured for student learning.

Beth Anne is amazing, without a doubt the best math professor I've had at Yale. She takes the time to work through multiple examples in class, which helps make the application of the methods so much more clear. The main weakness of the course was the way in which PDEs were only really touched in the last weak or two, so it was very rushed. I would suggest either getting to it earlier in the course or taking it out entirely so the class is only ordinary differential equations

There were many strengths, including the instructor Beth Anne V. Bennett. However, since I am reviewing the course itself and not the professor, I will talk more about the course. The course material is a little fast in the beginning, then it gets slower as the curriculum expands more generally to nth-order Ordinary Differential Equations (ODE's), and then picks back up again when you introduce the other concepts such as Laplace transformations, partial differential equations, series solutions, and Laplace's equations. One weakness of the course was the lack of stress of the conditions required to use each method: such as when to use integrating factors, Laplace's transformations, Method of Undetermined Coefficients, etc. Although I eventually learned these conditions, I had to spend many hours learning the different conditions. Also, another weakness is the lack of time spent on Partial Differential Equations (PDE's). Although Beth Anne V. Bennett said in the first lecture that we will only spend two weeks or so on PDE's, it was still a crunch for time in the end (you have to spend a lot of time solving just one problem). One other weakness is the fact that there are many problems that take a long time to do, and every test is a crunch for time (it really test how fast you can do each problem... occasionally I would get bored during the problem and work on another problem haha). FINALLY, you have to know at least some Linear Algebra, or at least know some matrix-based operations (Beth Anne V. Bennett was kind enough to do an optional review session at a separate time from lecture which covered everything we needed to know for the class).

Professor Bennett is an excellent lecturer. She is great at explaining concepts, extraordinarily organized, and very considerate of her students. The PSETs werent particularly time consuming, and fairly typical for what you would expect from a math course. The support for this class was subpar however. The TAs were not particularly helpful and office hours with Professor Bennett often were really full.

Strengths: The lectures were incredibly clear and thorough. Notes were posted online for every lecture; these notes were also very thorough. The homework is good practice, and the answers are in the back of the book (Dr. Bennett knows this), so doing the homework and checking the answers is a great way to solidify one's knowledge of the material.
Weaknesses: The course was graded very harshly, and the midterm exams were very difficult, beyond the scope of what was learned in class. Only about 15-18 people out of 82 earn an A, and many earn a C or worse. The TA's this year were not very helpful.

This class shouldn't include partial diff EQ. There is enough content without it and you don't get to understand it conceptually in the time we spend studying it. We just get equations without physical understanding, which is only slightly valuable. Beth Ann Bennet is incredible. Probably the best lecturer and professor I have had in a STEM class at Yale. She really cares about her students and spends so much time preparing for class.

This course was very fast, which is both a strength and a weakness as it takes practice to master all the methods and use them efficiently to solve problems in a timely manner. Sometimes it may go so fast that people get lost and its sometimes tough to catch up once you are behind, as all the material is cumulative. However, professor Bennett explains things really well and works with everyone to make sure everyone understands the material so its well taught and its not too tough to follow along and learn a lot.

Strength: very well organized
Not too much to say about an applied math course, it is what it is.
It would be nice to learn slightly more about PDEs - they seemed like a bit of an afterthought in this course.
The lectures are very good and I generally feel that they helped me learn the material.  The problem sets are related, although occasionally felt needlessly long.

The strength of this course is that is taught very well and a lot of material is covered with practical applications to keep engineering majors interested.  The weakness is that it is a lot of work.  To some extent, this is expected, as it is not easy material.  However, I believe that the problem sets could be a bit shorter and we would still have learned the subject well.

By the end I feel PDEs were crammed and we were told to read the lecture notes/textbook in addition to going overtime for classes in order to learn all the material, when I think it would've been better just not to learn the last few sections.

The teaching was fantastic. This includes both the lectures and the lecture notes which were incredibly easy to follow and read from. The only real weakness is the fact that some of the last homeworks were incredibly long, hard and time consuming, like absurdly hard. For these homework assignments it was less about understanding the material and more about writing out three pages of summations or pages containing the solution of just one hard to solve integral. These were unnecessary and I hope this gets changed for future years.
Professor Bennett was fantastic, but could not prevent diff eqs for being a relatively uninteresting subject. That's an impossible task.

Strengths:
I would say this course is true to its word: I did feel far more equipped to handle differential equations than when I went in.

Weaknesses:
If one takes this class at face value (i.e. ENAS, NOT proof-based math), I would say weaknesses are few and far between under Professor Bennet. Theres a lot of material, but we got through it in an organized and comprehensive manner.

Beth is an amazing professor who manages to go through A LOT of material very quickly - while explaining all of this material in a very straightforward and simple way. She is extremely good at "dumbing down" what could have otherwise been a very difficult and complicated subject.
The lectures notes posted online and extremely helpful and well structured. 
The problem sets, while long, are pretty fun to do!
The material is challenging - in a good way - and interesting.

The one weakness of this class was the long and hard exams - especially the first midterm, which was very difficult and stressful to do. It was the type of exam that you feel like crap afterwards, even if you were extremely well prepared.

The course is quite comprehensive, but leaves too little time for the last portion class (partial differentials). It is timed such that much of the last portion is covered very quickly and many smaller topics need to be self taught. I liked that the course focused far more on applications rather than Theory.

The course was taught very well, but the grading distribution was unfortunate. Since the tests were difficult, only a certain number of people got A's, B's, etc. If you had prior knowledge of linear algebra, there was a very unfair advantage on the second midterm thus causing a bit of discrepancy in the grades.
Very strong and clear format. I dont think partial differential equations should be covered.
Professor Bennett is a wonderful professor and is committed to helping the students understand the material!
Diff eqs are inherently sort of a dry subject, but for what it was, the course was pretty educational. Not fun really, but I didn't expect it to be. Not sure how it could be improved.

Strengths: It taught exactly what the course title says

Weaknesses: Very rushed class (too much content for 13 weeks), stressful class by nature of the grading/content/psets

This course was VERY well organized (all thanks to Professor Bennett I expect). The psets were fair and not too hard to work through on your own. The lectures weren't very engaging but they certainly taught the material well, and were very clear. The exams I found to be challenging (and unfair at times, with advantage to those who had taken Linear Algebra already, or with questions designed so that algebraic errors would propagate and cost you a lot of points). It sounds strange but I would suggest including one challenge question on each pset not found in the textbook that would really make students think about the concepts rather than the steps they'd memorized; one question where students were almost forced to go to office hours every week, you know? I don't feel like I have a great understanding of the ideas behind all the methods we used (but I sure do know how to use those methods!). Also as an engineer I will always cry for more application of these topics worked into the curriculum! It seemed very here and there.

Strength: Beth
Weakness: Maybe textbook
I feel like the sheer amount of content is too much, and most of the problem sets were all very long.
This course was well organized but very fast paced, and difficult to keep up with if you don't have a strong background in calculus.

The material is taught well. I always learned with Professor Bennett. She is a wonderful professor. Honestly, no weaknesses in the course. I would appreciate a review session before the exams. KEY NOTE: Study with the ODEs all mixed up because they will not be separated out on the exam. (example: exact equations, first order linear ODEs will all be mixed together)

Beth is extremely organized and a really great teacher. The level of difficulty in class/problem sets was pretty different from midterms/finals, in a bad way, meaning the exams were way harder. I don't mind a hard class, but that discrepancy kind of shocked me, so to improve it I would say provide practice material for any tests. I know it was Beth's first semester teaching the class, but in every other STEM course I've taken there has been practice material.

Lectures were clear and well organized, and the psets seemed to support class quite well. However, the questions on the exams were unlike what we had seen before in terms of complexity and combining material from across chapters. Without materials to help prepare for exams, we were left with only old psets and lecture notes, which didn't contain problems that were of the same caliber that we got on exams. More exam materials, such as a practice test, would have gone a long way.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who's interested in the topic! Make sure to take it after or concurrently with MATH 222/225, though.
This is an excellent course to take for any engineering student. Although it is not in the math department, this is basically a math class.
Yes! I loved it.
Yes, especially if taught by Bennett
Yes, definitely.

If you are only looking to get credit for a differential equations class, then take this class. But if you're looking for a deeper understanding of the math and and intellectual challenge, then this class isn't for you.

I would recommend itif you have a choice between taking this course or the math version of differential equations, definitely take this one. This course covers more of the topics and teaches you them betterhaving talked to some of my friends who took the math version they definitely didn't have as good an understanding of many parts of the class as we did in this course.

If you're engineering, you have to take it - take it with Beth or find her lecture notes somehow. I've heard not-so-great things about other professors. You have to do a lot of practice to really internalize concepts, and I thought the midterms were harder than the problem sets. It's cool material that is used everywhere in engineering so get excited to BE EMPLOYABLE.

Absolutely, if you like math or obviously if you need it for engineering. PLEASE try to take this with Beth Anne Bennett--she makes this class so much easier to understand than it would be with a bad lecturer. Psets are fine, just a few hours a week, and exams with her are hard but very fair. Interesting, challenging material but a lot of support if you need help and the psets teach you to understand everything. This is easily the best math class I've taken at Yale.
YES! Take it with Dr. Bennett! You will learn so much.

I took this course for my major, and probably wouldn't take it unless you need it for your major, but definitely try to take it with Professor Bennett! Also, take linear first if you can. You will be at a disadvantage if you haven't taken it.

I would recommend this course only if you were interested in solving differential equations for a very strong reason, like you are going to be solving differential equations in physics. This class is difficult, and the problem sets vary from week to week, some take 2 hours, some take 8. I would not recommend this course to anyone not interested in STEM, or anyone who does not plan on using the methods taught in this course in you career or future courses. However, you definitely learn how to solve differential equations, with applications in physics, such as forced and damp oscillations, which confused me in my introductory physics courses (I did not know how we solved certain equations in physics, but now I do!).

I would highly recommend this course if taught by Professor Bennett. Other versions of ENAS 194 (taught by Hui Cao or James Rolf) have a reputation of being extremely difficult. Professor Bennett really made the material much easier to understand.

I would only recommend this course to students who 1. Do not care about their GPA; 2. Are math gods; 3. Have the ability to take the course Credit/D/Fail. Dr. Bennett is an incredible lecturer and prepares thorough notes for every lecture, so, no matter what, you are guaranteed to learn A LOT from this course. However, Dr. Bennett's midterm exams are very difficult. They are essentially impossible to finish in the time allowed, and some of the problems on those tests were unlike any I had seen either in lecture or on the homework. To make matters worse, the grading is very harsh. Of 91 people originally taking the course, about 35 were to receive some sort of A and 35 to receive some sort of B, leaving the rest with a worse grade. Dr. Bennett informed us of this grading after the first midterm. This made many of us very stressed, and even caused 9 people to instantly drop the course. So, you cannot get an A in this course unless you are a math god. The competition in this course due to Bennett's grading is rather toxic. If you can take the course Credit/D/Fail, definitely do it. But if your GPA matters to you, stay away.

If you have the opportunity to take the course with a professor as great as Beth Anne Bennett, do it! I took this class more for the fun of it than anything, and I was not disappointed. However, I have heard bad things about the class in previous semesters, so I'm sure the quality of the teaching has a big impact on your perception of the course.

I would definitely encourage any engineering or applied science student to take this class as the methods taught in this class to solve problems are applicable for most STEM fields and professor Bennett teaches the material really well. Even if you are not an engineering student, it may be fun (though challenging) to take this class for fun if you would like to learn how to solve this class of problems (its quite fun!) without getting too deep into the theoretical details that the math major differential equations class will get into.
Yes
Only take if required for your major.

If you are interested in differential equations, the class will teach you how to evaluate them but not give any real understanding of their mathematical significance.  If you are only interested in applications, then I would recommend it.

Though a difficult course with difficult grading (about 35% of the class gets an A or A-), I would recommend this course to another student because it is taught extremely well and many practical examples are also covered, which can be missing from a traditional math class.
I actually enjoyed the course a lot, even though it felt tedious many times, it was nice that the material was relatively easy to get a grasp on.
The teaching is fantastic. Take this class if you want to take a differential equations class at Yale.
I would recommend it only if they need it for their major. I didn't, so I was kicking myself the whole semester for not having taken something else. That said, I did fine in the course.
If its with Professor Bennet and they want to learn to solve a lot of different types of partial differential equations (but are okay with not knowing the proofs behind those methods), I would.
Most people do not take ENAS 194 for fun. However, I would recommend this class even if it is not one of your requirements - given that Professor Bennett is the one teaching it!
Yes.
Yes. It was very helpful for my major - physics

It's a good class if you need to fulfill the math requirement for the physics major (which I needed to do). You learn a lot about differential equations and how to solve them, and the psets are pretty chill.
Only if you are extremely into math and/or it is required for your major would I take this class.

If it weren't a requirement, I probably wouldn't recommend it because I haven't quite experienced its usefulness yet, but as for math courses, I enjoyed it. But the exams were pretty rough for me so then again maybe not. I'd say opt for a more inherently interesting QR credit.

I think this is a course I would recommend to a student who wants to gain a deeper understanding in Math who isn't a math major. The concepts are interesting but I will say that this class is very hard and very much kicked my butt but it was cool learning some sick math. Also the professor really cares about the students and enjoys teaching
Yes, it was well taught and I learned a lot.

Yes, definitely take this with Professor Bennett. She is incredibly clear in her explanations, writes great class notes, and clearly cares a lot about teaching well. I wasnt required to take this course, but Im glad that I did because it was useful, interesting, and very well taught.
Yes! Its a lot of material, but under Beth, the course is taught well and fair. Good intro to ordinary and partial DEs

Unless you need to take this class for a major, I don't think there's much mathematical or intellectual curiosity you'll satisfy by taking the class. I only took it because of my major, and I didn't enjoy it. For most of the class, I felt like we were simply learning the names of methods and memorizing a very convoluted series of steps to get the answer. I vaguely knew what differential equations were before starting the class, but most topics were newly introduced to me. I was confused for more than half the classes, but I also did not read the textbook before class. I would also recommend having experience in linear algebra BEFORE taking this class. There were a few chapters on systems of linear equations, eigenvalues, matrices, etc. that took me a long time to learn even outside of doing the problem set. I also felt like the classes were too packed with material, and we had to rush to finish everything.
Take it if you need to take it and are well-prepared in calculus.  The problem sets are extremely time consuming and I found it difficult to do well despite my best efforts.

YES. Professor Bennett is wonderful in all ways. She can teach the material well. She writes the best lecture notes. She is always available via office hours. My only criticism is that the grade distribution at the end of the course was tough relative to typical Yale grades.
Definitely take this class if you want/need to learn how to do calculations better.  It is hard, but you will improve a palpable amount.
Yes, especially any hard science major who wants to learn about DEs. There weren't a ton of applications, so don't be scared off by the fact that this is an engineering class.
